He was well-educated for his time, attending the
in canon law, all achieved between 1394 and 1415; he attained an additional doctorate—in civil law—by 1436.
Lichton followed an ecclesiastical career simultaneously with his studies. The first notice of this career comes in 1392, when he was
by 1395, holding this position into the following year, 1396.
met to elect a new bishop, and on 18 May Lichton was elected
to receive consecration, and was consecrated on 8 March 1415, at
Lichton enjoyed an amicable relationship with the most powerful magnate in the area,
Alexander Stewart, Lord of Badenoch and Earl of Mar
, as Lichton appears to have suffered no harassment, attended the latter's marriage to
back in 1404 and procured for him an annulment of that marriage when Stewart chose to remarry in 1415.
Lichton was probably a kinsman of Stewart, as he is described as a kinsman of Stewart's uncle,
, the man who ruled Scotland as governor until his death in 1420.
, Aberdeen; the west front dates from Lichton's episcopate.
, in 1421, Lichton was chosen as his successor, and was translated to the
in early April 1422, on the authority of
, in order to take Lichton's oath to the
without forcing him to travel to Rome.
It is of note that Lichton had already been in possession of the prebend of
but attached to Aberdeen Cathedral by Lichton's time.
As Bishop of Aberdeen, Lichton was one of its greatest builders. The
noted that he began to rebuild the cathedral,
gave a description of his rebuilding, noting that although he finished the walls and two
, the third belltower remained unfinished at his death.
Licthon also constructed a new chapel dedicated to
, and donated much of his own money to new service books and vestments, as well as to the reconstruction of the cathedral.
He also authored several legal and religious texts, though none have survived.
Henry was frequently used as an ambassador by the king,
, Henry was one of the men sent to England to arrange the ransom of King James - held in England for most of his youth, not being released until 1424.
On 9 June 1425, he and other prelates received a safe-conduct from King
enabling them to travel through England on their way to visit
In 1428, Henry was the leader of an embassy sent to King
for a marriage proposal and to renew the
and in January 1430, was sent into England for discussion of various grievances.
On 31 March 1434, Lichton is found in attendance at the
, though no more details of his activities there have survived.
Lichton's death cannot be precisely dated. It fell between 11 November (
it is probable that he died on either 12 or 14 December, because these were the anniversaries given to him in the 15th century and the 16th century respectively.
He was buried in his new chapel, the one dedicated to St John the Evangelist.
As a churchman, Lichton could never marry and did not; he did however father a bastard, a daughter named Janet, who appeared in the records receiving
